The **1924 Winter Olympics** , officially known as the **I Olympic Winter
Games** ([French](/wiki/French_language "French language"): Les _Iers Jeux
olympiques d 'hiver_), were a winter [multi-sport event](/wiki/Multi-
sport_event "Multi-sport event") which was held in 1924 in
[Chamonix](/wiki/Chamonix "Chamonix"),
[France](/wiki/France_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "France at the 1924 Winter
Olympics"). Originally called _Semaine Internationale des Sports d 'Hiver_
("International Winter Sports Week") and held in association with the [1924
Summer Olympics](/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics "1924 Summer Olympics"), the
sports competitions were held at the foot of [Mont Blanc](/wiki/Mont_Blanc
"Mont Blanc") in [Chamonix](/wiki/Chamonix "Chamonix"), and [Haute-
Savoie](/wiki/Haute-Savoie "Haute-Savoie"), France between January 25 and
February 5, 1924.[1] The Games were organized by the French Olympic Committee,
and were in retrospect designated by the [International Olympic
Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic
Committee") (IOC) as the I Olympic Winter Games.

The tradition of holding the Winter Olympics in the same year as the Summer
Olympics would continue until [1992](/wiki/1992_Winter_Olympics "1992 Winter
Olympics"), after which the current practice of holding a Winter Olympics in
the second year after each Summer Olympics began.

Although Figure Skating had been an Olympic event in both
[London](/wiki/1908_Summer_Olympics "1908 Summer Olympics") and
[Antwerp](/wiki/1920_Summer_Olympics "1920 Summer Olympics"), and Ice Hockey
had been an event in Antwerp, the winter sports had always been limited by the
season. In 1921, at the convention of the IOC in [Lausanne](/wiki/Lausanne
"Lausanne"), there was a call for equality for winter sports, and after much
discussion it was decided to organize an "international week of winter sport"
in 1924 in Chamonix.

##
Highlights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Highlights")]

### Day 2[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Day 2")]

The first gold medal awarded in the Olympic Winter games was won by [Charles
Jewtraw](/wiki/Charles_Jewtraw "Charles Jewtraw") of the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States") in the 500-meter speed skate.

### Day 4[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Day 4")]

[Sonja Henie](/wiki/Sonja_Henie "Sonja Henie"), at just eleven years old,
skates in the ladies' figure skating competition. Although she finishes last,
she becomes popular with fans, and will take the gold at the next three Winter
Olympics.

### Day 6[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Day 6")]

Finding himself in a unique situation, the figure skater [Gillis
Grafström](/wiki/Gillis_Grafstr%C3%B6m "Gillis Grafström") is the first one
ever to successfully defend his Summer Olympics title at the Winter Olympics.

### Day 8[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Day 8")]

The [Canadian](/wiki/Canada "Canada") ice-hockey team finished their
qualifying round with 3 wins, scoring a total of 85 goals against Switzerland,
Czechoslovakia, and Sweden without surrendering even a single goal against.

### Day
10[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Day 10")]

Finding themselves in the same situation Gillis Grafström, the Canadian ice-
hockey team is the last ever to successfully defend its Summer Olympics title
at the Winter Olympics. Canada would dominate ice hockey in early Olympic
competition, winning six of the first seven gold medals awarded.

###
Epilogue[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Epilogue")]

At the closing of the games a prize was awarded for a sport that did not lend
itself very well for tournaments: [Pierre de
Coubertin](/wiki/Pierre_de_Coubertin "Pierre de Coubertin") presented a prize
for 'alpinisme' ([mountaineering](/wiki/Mountaineering "Mountaineering")) to
[Charles Granville Bruce](/wiki/Charles_Granville_Bruce "Charles Granville
Bruce"), the leader of the expedition that tried to climb [Mount
Everest](/wiki/Mount_Everest "Mount Everest") in 1922.

For the first time in the history of the modern Olympics, the host country, in
this case, France, failed to win any [gold medals](/wiki/Gold_medals "Gold
medals"), finishing with three bronze medals. This feat would later occur at
the [next Winter Olympics](/wiki/1928_Winter_Olympics "1928 Winter Olympics")
in [St. Moritz](/wiki/St._Moritz "St. Moritz") where Switzerland won only a
single bronze medal, the lowest ever output by a host nation at an Olympics.
Later host nations to finish without gold medals included Canada at the [1976
Summer Olympics](/wiki/1976_Summer_Olympics "1976 Summer Olympics") in
[Montreal](/wiki/Montreal "Montreal") and [1988 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/1988_Winter_Olympics "1988 Winter Olympics") in
[Calgary](/wiki/Calgary "Calgary") and [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia
"Yugoslavia") at the [1984 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984
Winter Olympics") in [Sarajevo](/wiki/Sarajevo "Sarajevo").

In 1925, the IOC decided to organize Olympic Winter Games every four years,
independent of the Olympic Games proper, and recognized the International
Winter Sports Week as the first Olympic Winter games in retrospect.

In 1974 the final individual medal of Chamonix 1924 was presented. [Anders
Haugen](/wiki/Anders_Haugen "Anders Haugen"), who until then had been recorded
as finishing fourth in the [ski jumping
event](/wiki/Ski_jumping_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Ski jumping at the 1924
Winter Olympics"), received a bronze medal. After fifty years an error had
been discovered in the score of [Thorleif Haug](/wiki/Thorleif_Haug "Thorleif
Haug").

In 2006, the IOC confirmed that the awarded medals to 1924
[curling](/wiki/Curling "Curling") teams were official. The IOC verified that
curling was officially part of the program, after the _[Glasgow
Herald](/wiki/Glasgow_Herald "Glasgow Herald")_ newspaper filed a claim on
behalf of the families of the team.[2]

## Events[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Events")]

Medals were awarded in 16 events contested in 5 sports (9 disciplines). Many
sources do not list curling and the military patrol, or list them as
demonstration events. However, no such designation was made in 1924. In
February 2006 the International Olympic Committee (IOC) ruled that curling was
a full part of the Olympic program, and have included the medals awarded in
the official count.

## Venues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Venues")]

Main article: [Venues of the 1924 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/Venues_of_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Venues of the 1924 Winter
Olympics")

  * [La Piste de Bobsleigh des Pellerins](/wiki/La_Piste_de_Bobsleigh_des_Pellerins "La Piste de Bobsleigh des Pellerins") – Bobsleigh
  * [Le Tremplin Olympique du Mont](/wiki/Le_Tremplin_Olympique_du_Mont "Le Tremplin Olympique du Mont") – Ski jumping, Nordic combined (ski jumping)
  * [Stade Olympique de Chamonix](/wiki/Stade_Olympique_de_Chamonix "Stade Olympique de Chamonix") – Cross-country skiing, Curling, Figure skating, Ice hockey, Military patrol, Nordic combined (cross-country skiing), and Speed skating

## Participating
nations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Participating nations")]

Athletes from 16 nations competed in the first Winter Olympic Games.
[Germany](/wiki/Germany_at_the_Olympics "Germany at the Olympics") was banned
from competing in the games, and instead hosted a series of games called
[Deutsche Kampfspiele](/wiki/Deutsche_Kampfspiele "Deutsche Kampfspiele").

## Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1924_Winter_Olympics&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** The official website of the Olympic Movement now treats Men's Military Patrol at the 1924 games as an event within the sport of [Biathlon](/wiki/Biathlon "Biathlon").[3][4] However the 1924 Official Report treats it as an event and discipline within what was then called Skiing and is now called [Nordic Skiing](/wiki/Nordic_Skiing "Nordic Skiing").[5][6]
